key_findings: LLM-First Search (LFS) eliminates the need for pre-defined search hyperparameters by allowing LLMs to autonomously control their own search process through internal scoring mechanisms, making it more adaptable across tasks of varying difficulty compared to fixed-parameter methods like MCTS.

The method addresses a critical limitation of existing search approaches like Monte Carlo Tree Search and Tree-of-Thoughts Breadth First Search, which rely on hardcoded policies and external heuristics that require manual tuning for different tasks.

LFS enables context-sensitive reasoning by empowering the LLM to evaluate whether to pursue current search paths or explore alternative branches based on its own assessment, removing dependency on task-specific adaptation requirements.

The approach was evaluated on structured problem-solving tasks including Countdown numbers game and Sudoku puzzles, demonstrating practical applicability to combinatorial optimization and constraint satisfaction problems.

The research contributes to the broader trend of using increased test-time compute for improved LLM reasoning and planning, offering a more flexible alternative to traditional search algorithms in AI problem-solving applications.
limitations: Limited evaluation scope with only two specific problem domains (Countdown and Sudoku) tested
Reliance on LLM internal scoring mechanisms may introduce inconsistency or bias in search decisions
future_work: Extension to broader range of problem domains beyond combinatorial puzzles
Comparison with additional search algorithms and optimization methods

resource_requirements.compute_requirements: Standard LLM inference compute for test-time search
resource_requirements.data_requirements: Countdown and Sudoku problem instances for evaluation

problem_addressed: Eliminates the need for manual hyperparameter tuning and task-specific adaptation in LLM-based search algorithms by enabling autonomous search control
